It's a marketplace for micro-internships and mentorships with professionals at multiple tech companies. Sort of like airbnb experience.

The second layer we are building on top of that is a credentialing system, which students build a history of classes they've taken, for how long, with who and reviews about your skills from those mentors who taught you.

My guess is that in the future, when looking for a job, the question recruiters ask about your education won't be "where did you go to?", but rather "who did you go to?"
www.xplain.us

One of the main problems I see in higher-education is that is a zero-sum game. And diplomas based on majors are a currency.

If I graduate from *x* university, with a degree in *y* with a GPA of *n*, and you graduate from *x*, majored in *y* with *n* GPA, when we go to the job market, our currencies are worth the same. And graduates are in a zero-sum game in the job market.

The university acts like a central bank, keeping the number of people they let in as a way to keep a strong brand. If a university enrolls too many people, the value of the currency goes down.

I was majoring in econ and then I started a double major with computer science. After that, because no-one in my university had graduated with that combination before, I wasn't competing with the economists, because I know how to code. And I wasn't competing with computer scientists, since I have a background in economics.

If instead of having majors, we build our own unique, one-of-a-kind curriculum, we can escape this zero-sum competition.

Rn the university curriculum is like the cable packaged channels. They sell you channels that you are clearly not going to watch.

The future will be more like your Youtube feed, in the way that yours looks totally different from mine.

The people who end up creating big things either create jobs that didn't exist before or have an unique combination of skills and decide to use them in a new way. What about having micro-apprenticeships from different types of professionals in different fields so every students can create their own unique combination of skills acquired from different professions ?

Non CS

Before having any work experience, blogging and podcasting helps a lot (it can show to everyone you’re consistent, have some sort of strong work ethic and that you’re smart), but the best I know about is your network (podcasting helps for this), learn to cold email busy people and offer to take some of their work off their plate (even boring work) - read “how to get ahead” by zak slayback and follow him on twitter, best career advice out there. Hands down.

Do not go to “networking events”, they suck ass. No one worth knowing goes there.

Interview in a podcast the smartest people you can find (learn to cold-email) . Write blog posts about the greatest books you can find (some of the best blogs I know about combine different books that most people wouldn’t think of connecting together) .

If you’re looking for a job, have in mind that you are in a zero-sum competition, you have to out-compete other people. But don’t do it by imitating, you’ll never win that way. Combine different areas of interest/expertise in a unique way to stand out from the competition

Society without social credits it’s  no society.

Exactly. P2P education and credentials are the future. Learn from many people who have experience and then get credentials from them to solve information-asymmetry when looking for a job. ^^^ Then you'd have to tie students to a mentor who has status with whoever the student is trying to impress yeah?
yea, but also the amount of mentors vouching for you. that principle applies to yout reputation on github and stack overflow.
At that point you're doing more networking than education
the mentor doesn't need to have "high status", only status as "a great teacher", "difficult teacher" or "teacher with reputation of having grate students"
Facts
So are you trying to measure the students status or the mentors status?
because if you have a reputation system (like github) but for mentors, you can leverage that for the students

student status as of "skills in a particular field" , "how well collaborates with peers and which peers", "how fast they are advancing in the field", "which subjects are they connecting that nobody has connected before", "what soft-skills are mentors perceiving that they have"

and status in mentors as of "ability to transfer skills to students", "how recurrent are their students", "labor experience in the field" , "feedback from employers after hiring their students"
I gochu
So as a company couldn't you focus on building and measuring the status of the mentors
Do that really well
Then let the mentors accredit the students
yea, working on it 😉  but is not as simple as that. tons of game theory involved to prevent fraud.
That is a very good point
I've been looking a lot into how the education market can become more horizontal (as opposed to vertical like a university) and accreditation & networking are the two big pain points

I like the bitcoin model for this:

If you are selling a coffee for btc ($), it's so low risk that you won't even wait for the miners to verify the transaction. If you're selling a house ($$$), you'll want to see at leas 7 miners verify the transaction.

Same with employers, the higher the position they are hiring, the more mentors and the more time-stamped reviews linked to time spent with those mentors studying the subject, the more trusted the signal becomes (proof of work, really)

That way, for fraudsters, it becomes more expensive as they go and risk of getting caught increases (since more people know of his attempt to cheat/bribe)
That's really interesting
so your business model is kinda like a exchange between money and status (or verification of skill)
our business model is like airbnb. we take a small percentage of the transaction on the consumer side
Hmmm
So like a frat but for getting hired instead of getting laid
^^ your metaphor of dating and social status
lol I thought of it as each mentor being their own university (they run their own admissions) , but if you wanna call it that...
running their own admissions is interesting
Universities invest a lot in their admissions so letting mentors pick their students could shake things up
What kinda effect do you think that will have?
It’ll just make less sense to stay in the institutions, for both students and teachers.

Rn we have diploma-hyperinflation. Going to university used to be worth it cause very few people graduated. How is that a dishonest question? Seems like a fair criticism given that public education is 100% free. @Jeremy B, most proponents of the choice movement advocate for a voucher system. Basically, the government directly gives citizens who choose to opt out of the public education system the same amount of money they'd spend on them if they remained in the education system (varies by state, but roughly 8-10K/year). So instead of the 8-10K/year/pupil going to a public school, it goes directly to the family to spend on private education services. The idea is that this would introduce market competition to public schools, resulting in student outcomes improving and the cost of education becoming more efficient and going down. Essentially, it allows everyone to access the same amount of funds regardless of socio-economic background and gives the the *choice* to spend it how they want to. Charter schools are a less extreme version of this, but same idea: competition for public schools.
It's like a government-funded allowance for private education

Voucher systems are one thing, and I understand there is plenty of debate around the pros/cons of a voucher system. However the tweet posted just said to privatize education, seeming to argue that public education should just be done away with, which is something entirely different. But I might be misinterpreting it 🤷🏻‍♂️
